Sri Lanka

August 2013 
 
 
 
 
Proposed Administration of Grants  
Nepal: Building Climate Resilience of Watersheds in 
Mountain Eco-Regions 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public prior to Board consideration in accordance with 
ADB’s Public Communications Policy 2011. Subject to any revisions required following Board 
consideration, this document is deemed final.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) proposed 
administration of a grant to be provided by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategic 
Climate Fund1 and (ii) proposed partial administration of a grant to be provided by the Nordic 
Development Fund (NDF), both to Nepal for Building Climate Resilience of Watersheds in 
Mountain Eco-Regions.2 
 
2.  The  project  aims  to  provide  access  to  more  reliable  water  resources  for  domestic 
purposes and irrigation for communities living in the watersheds of Nepal’s river systems, which 
are significantly vulnerable to climate change.3 The watersheds selected lie in six districts in the 
Far-Western Development Region: Achham, Baitaidi, Bajhang, Bajura, Dadeldhura, and Doti. 
Access to and reliability of water resources will be improved through a participatory program of 
integrated watershed management with interventions in upland areas to increase surface water 
storage  and  groundwater  recharge.  Communities  now  recognize  that  water  resources  are 
limited. They have expressed their commitment toward protecting and enhancing their water 
resources. The project will demonstrate ways to protect water sources while at the same time 
developing them for efficient use. The communities in the project area will have more reliable 
water supplies in the dry season. Major beneficiaries will be women and disadvantaged groups.4 
As the first large-scale intervention by ADB in watershed management in Nepal, the project will 
demonstrate participatory watershed management planning and build the capacity of all levels 
of government for integrated watershed development, specifically focusing on water resources. 
It is intended that lessons from this project will influence the ways in which rural water supply 
and irrigation projects are designed. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The  project  is  one  of  five  components  in  Nepal’s  Strategic  Program  for  Climate 
Resilience (SPCR), which was endorsed by the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience Sub-
Committee in June 2011.5 The SPCR aims to build long-term climate resilience through an 
integrated water resource and ecosystem-based approach, and to yield lessons on how best to 
build  resilience  in  vulnerable  mountain  regions.  It  responds  to  the  government’s  National 
Adaptation Programme of Action (NAPA) for climate change, which was finalized in September 
2010. The NAPA promotes a watershed and landscape-level approach to deal with issues 
related to food security, biodiversity loss, water scarcity, energy use, settlements, public health, 
and governance. Climate variability and change in Nepal is projected to exacerbate existing 
threats to food, water, and livelihood security through alterations in the quantity and timing of 
precipitation and runoff, more atmospheric water vapor and evaporation, and progressive loss of 
glacier and snowpack storage in basin headwaters. 
                                                
1  Under the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience financed by the Strategic Climate Fund. 
2  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
3  ADB provided project preparatory technical assistance.  
4  Disadvantaged groups are defined in a supporting document, Gender and Social Inclusion Plan (accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
5  The other four SPCR components deal with building resilience to climate-induced hazards through improved flood 
forecasting  and  early  warning  systems,  managing  climate  change  risk  in  development  planning,  protecting 
endangered flora and fauna, and providing incentives for private sector assistance in climate change adaptation. 
The sub-committee is the decision-making body that oversees the operations and activities of the program. It 
comprises representatives of contributor and eligible recipient countries to the fund.

2 
4.  The selected watersheds for project investment are in the West Seti subbasin of the 
Karnali River Basin. The subbasin originates from the snowfields and glaciers around the twin 
peaks of Api and Nampa in the south-facing slopes of the main Himalayas. The Lower West 
Seti  and  Budhi  Ganga  watersheds  have  been  selected  for  the  project  because  a  study 
conducted during project design assessed their vulnerability to climate change as high; their 
population  is  estimated  at  496,205. 6  Annual  precipitation  in  the  subbasin  varies  from 
743 millimeters to 3,351 millimeters under current climate conditions, about 75% of which falls 
during a 3-4 month monsoon season. Water scarcity is a significant and widespread problem 
among these communities, occurring every year in the dry season.7 The mean per capita 
income based on a household survey is NRs21,934 per year.8 More than 85% of households in 
these watersheds live in scattered dwellings close to natural springs and patches of more gently 
sloping land. They have subsistence lifestyles based on mixed agriculture, grazing activity, and 
collection of non-timber forest products.  
5.  The watershed areas have average slopes of almost 30 degrees, encompassing narrow 
valleys  with  perennial  streams.  There  is  limited  cultivatable  land  in  river  flats  and  on  the 
hillsides, where there is some land with a slope of less than 20 degrees. Transport and other 
services are severely limited as most settlements have only foot-track access. Each of the six 
districts in the two watersheds has a small town with road access, but these roads may be 
blocked by landslides during monsoon periods. There are agricultural markets only in the district 
centers. The towns have electricity supply but generation shortages limit it to 5–10 hours a day 
depending on location and season. Villages have even more limited access to electricity.  
6.  Global climate model projections downscaled for Nepal for 2030–2061 were analyzed for 
the subbasin during project design.9 A temperature rise of at least 2°C by the mid-21st century 
is  projected  to  affect  the  hydrological  cycle,  which  in  turn  will  have  an  impact  on  water 
availability, runoff, and the discharge regime of rivers.10 In general, climate change projections 
show that precipitation will slightly increase in the West Seti subbasin. Precipitation will increase 
in pre-monsoon months and decrease in the monsoon, whereas a mixed trend (both increasing 
and decreasing) is projected in the project sub-watersheds in the winter and after the monsoon. 
Some models project increasing trends and others project decreasing trends in annual water 
yield and actual evapotranspiration. In general, climate change projections show that annual 
river flow volume will slightly decrease. However, it is difficult to make conclusions regarding 
precipitation and flow trends. Uncertainty is the main risk that can be attributed to climate 
change. Another change reported was increasing intensity of rainfall, particularly during rain 
showers  in  the  pre-monsoon  period. This  increased  intensity  would  reduce  the  amount of 
infiltration and groundwater recharge. Development of storage facilities is an effective way to 
                                                
6   International Water Management Institute. 2012. Climate Change and Vulnerability Mapping in Watersheds in 
Middle and High Mountains of Nepal. Kathmandu. (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
7   Source: Socioeconomic survey of households in seven sample areas, conducted through project preparatory 
technical assistance. 
8  2011, Nepal Living Standards Survey III, reports mean per capita income at NRs23.893, and median per capita 
income at NRs16,094 for communities living in rural hills in Mid-Western Development Region and Far-Western 
Development Region.  
9   Through ADB support in 2011–2012 the Asian Disaster Preparedness Center downscaled five global circulation 
models for Nepal using three different regional circulation models. The data is posted on the Department of 
Hydrology and Meteorology’s web portal.  
10   J.H. Christensen et al. 2007. Regional Climate Projections. Quoted in S. Solomon et al, eds. 2007. Climate 
Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report of 
the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press. p. 882.

3 
cope with temporal and spatial variability in water resources.11 
 
7.  The  project  is  in  Nepal's  confirmed  project  pipeline  for  ADB  administration  and 
contributes  to  three  of  the  country  sector  outputs  for  2012–2014:  (i)  sustainable  rural 
infrastructure,  (ii)  accountable  service  delivery,  and  (iii)  increased  representation  of  target 
groups in governance structures. The project conforms to ADB’s Water Operational Plan (2011–
2020) and supports its priority of integrated water resource management to strengthen the 
water–food nexus.12 The design of the proposed project is based on experience and techniques 
developed by the Department of Soil Conservation and Watershed Management (DSCWM), 
lessons  from  international  nongovernment  organizations  and  research  organizations,  and 
international and national experience in watershed management.13 It aims to tie in with Nepal’s 
local adaptation plans of action on climate change.14 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The expected impact will be that climate resilience in Nepal’s mountain communities is 
improved.  The  project’s  outcome  will  be  that  selected  communities  that  are  significantly 
vulnerable to climate change have access to more reliable water resources. About 45,000 
households are expected to benefit from improved water availability during the dry season to 
support domestic and agricultural uses. The spring or surface water sources are expected to 
become more reliable; the dry season water yield will either remain the same or increase.  
C.  Outputs 
9.  To achieve its expected outcome, the project will have four outputs: (i) participating 
communities  have  improved  catchment  management  and  new  or  improved  water  storage 
infrastructure; (ii) communities and government manage water and land in an integrated and 
inclusive manner within watersheds; (iii) government adopts knowledge-based approaches for 
integrated water and land management and improved water reliability and accessibility in the 
wake of climate change; and (iv) project management support is provided. 
 
10.  Water source catchment management and storage infrastructure. The project will 
be implemented through about 100 community-based subprojects. Communities will manage 
catchment areas for development and protection of their water sources (springs and streams). 
This will include: (i) protection of the area surrounding the water source, and preparation and 
implementation of water source catchment management plans;15 (ii) treatment of gully erosion, 
and slope and landslide stabilization that threatens the water sources, water infrastructure, and 
beneficiary  communities;  (iii)  construction  of  water  collection  chambers,  spring  boxes  or 
infiltration galleries; (iv) construction of water conservation ponds and storage for irrigation and 
                                                
11  International Water Management Institute. The Assessment and Management of Water Resources under Current 
and Future Climate Conditions in the West Seti Subbasin, Nepal. Unpublished (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2). 
12    ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020. Manila. 
13  Some lessons include the need for better understanding of the link between the hydrologic cycle and land 
management,  planning  development  according  to  watershed  rather  than  administrative  boundaries,  and  a 
participatory planning approach. 
14  Under the Nepal Climate Change Support Programme of the Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment. 
15  Communities will establish the catchment area for the water source and define measures to manage land use, 
including regulating grazing, and fodder and firewood collection in the catchment. The executing agency will make 
agreements with community development groups on the responsibility of managing and protecting the catchment 
area, and introduce productive conservation measures such as planting of fruit and fodder trees and grass, and 
sustainable agroforestry.

4 
livestock; and (v) construction of drinking water storage tanks and tap stands. Water storage will 
help sustain the use of limited water during the dry season, thereby reducing the time people 
(especially  women)  spend  collecting  water,  and  increasing  the  irrigated  agricultural  area. 
Catchment improvement measures will help stabilize or augment the yield of water sources. 
 
11.  Inclusive  and  integrated  management  of  water  and  land.  Implementation  of 
subprojects will particularly promote water conservation in the catchment areas and tackle 
shortage issues that result in additional labor for women or pose difficulties for disadvantaged 
groups, who often have access only to less reliable water sources and suffer disproportionally in 
case of water shortage. The project will also provide participating communities with education 
and facilitate programs on water conservation practices (including micro-irrigation), methods for 
maintaining  soil  moisture  in  agriculture,  grazing  and  fodder  management,  and  ways  to 
regenerate  vegetative  cover.  The  project  will  strengthen  the  DSCWM’s  capacity  in  sub-
watershed management planning to improve water security and boost watershed resilience. 
Sub-watershed management plans will be prepared that describe the watersheds’ biophysical 
and  socioeconomic  conditions  and  challenges,  and  build  a  geographic  information  system 
database  of  existing  water  infrastructure  and  water-related  development  interventions. 
Community-driven interventions for water source catchment management and enhancement will 
be included. The watershed planning process will reinforce the DSCWM’s capacity to determine 
and monitor priority interventions, and the department can use the  geographic information 
system database in planning its future programs. 
 
12.  Lessons for improving access to and reliability of water resources. As the project 
will be implemented in six districts, this output will focus on documenting and sharing lessons 
from  project  implementation  to  all  DSCWM  staff  through  strategic  and  targeted  technical 
assistance. A knowledge management plan will be implemented, with activities to document and 
incorporate lessons into country programs, and to foster knowledge sharing among country 
stakeholders and in international climate change forums. The DSCWM’s capacity to monitor the 
impacts of project interventions will be strengthened through preparation of a management 
information system and expertise in benefit monitoring and evaluation. Other evaluations will be 
conducted on pertinent topics such as changes in hydrology due to catchment management 
measures,  how  communities  negotiate  water  allocations,  behavioral  change  in  collective 
management  of  interventions,  and  demand  management.  Project  experiences,  impact 
assessments, and lessons will be shared globally as part of the SPCR’s global learning support 
program. This output will be financed by the NDF. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
 
13.  The project is estimated to cost $30.11 million (Table 1).

5

14.  The ADB Strategic Climate Fund will provide grant cofinancing equivalent to $23.54 
million, to be administered by ADB (footnote 1). NDF will provide grant cofinancing equivalent to 
$4.63 million (€3.6 million), to be partially administered by ADB.16 The Government of Nepal will 
provide $1.94 million equivalent. The financing plan is in Table 2.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The DSCWM will be the executing agency. It will appoint a project director to head a 
project management unit (PMU) to handle project implementation. The district soil conservation 
offices  in  Baitadi,  Dadeldhura,  and  Doti  districts  will  be  responsible  for  subproject 
implementation. Policy direction will be provided by an interagency steering committee. The 
PMU will be based in Dadeldhura, with a full-time project director appointed by the DSCWM at 
class II level. The project director will reside in Dadeldhura but frequently visit Kathmandu on 
project business. The DSCWM will recruit from the market or depute 36 mid-level technicians 
for full-time field-based project work, and will designate three district soil conservation officers 
as environment officers for the project. The government will depute an account officer and 
accountant to work in the PMU. Senior consultant specialists will support the PMU and the 
district  soil  conservation  offices.  To  ensure  an  efficient  project  start,  the  government  has 
requested that ADB undertake the shortlisting, evaluation, and ranking of the lead firms and 
their proposals. Contract negotiations, and approval and signing of contracts will remain the 
government's responsibility, with ADB assistance and oversight.  
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the project administration manual.17

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
17.  The  yield  of  many  local  water  sources  in  the  hills  (springs  and  small  streams)  is 
declining, especially during the dry season, because of deforestation and land degradation in 
the catchment areas of these sources. The effects of climate change might further aggravate 
the situation, as the amount and timing of rainfall is expected to be altered, there may be less 
snow melt, and actual evapotranspiration may increase. Therefore, the project emphasizes the 
restoration and protection of such catchment areas, along with building capacity of communities 
for catchment management. An agreement with beneficiary communities to create catchment 
management areas in which grazing and fodder and forest products are regulated will be a 
precondition  for  project  assistance.  Catchment  restoration  and  protection  will  stabilize  and

7 
improve the yield of local water sources in the medium term. To mitigate acute daily water 
shortage in the short term, the project will provide new or improved water intake and water 
storage facilities where possible. To avoid failure and/or high operation and maintenance costs, 
the  project  emphasizes  a  high  standard  of  design  and  construction  for  this  infrastructure. 
Operation and maintenance plans will be prepared and implemented for each management 
area within a subproject. Soil and water interventions will include landslide stabilization and 
drainage works, hill slope and gully erosion control, bioengineering works for slope stabilization, 
land terracing, water intake structures such as spring boxes and infiltration galleries, water 
transmission pipelines, drinking water storage tanks, conservation ponds, water storage for 
irrigation, and water troughs for livestock. Organizing and training of the local community for 
catchment  management  and  maintenance  of  the  new  or  improved  infrastructure  will  be 
incorporated into the early stages of subproject development. 
B.  Economic and Financial 
18.  The  economic  and  financial  analyses  focused  on  the  economic  feasibility  of  three 
sample subprojects.18 For all three, quantified benefits were assessed by comparing present 
crop production with the production expected after the introduction of new or more reliable 
irrigation water supply through the development of water storage facilities. For the Dadeldhura 
and Doti subprojects, benefits also accrue from the time savings for households collecting water 
during the dry season. The economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) estimated for the three 
subprojects are 14.2% for Bajura, 21.4% for Dadeldhura, and 14.9% for Doti. All are not highly 
sensitive to changes in key cost and benefit variables, but for Bajura and Doti some changes of 
key variables tested in the sensitivity analysis lead to EIRRs below 12%. In particular, the EIRR 
of the Doti subproject would decrease to 11.2% if costs increased by 10% and benefits were 
reduced by 10% throughout the project life. Under the same scenario, the EIRR of the Bajura 
subproject would decrease to 10.7%, and to 10.8% if only 80% of the command area were 
developed, and to 11.9% if benefits were delayed 1 year. The subprojects remain viable since 
significant benefits have not been quantified. 
19.  The project is expected to benefit at least 45,000 households with more reliable water 
resources for irrigation, drinking, and other domestic uses, or for livestock, especially during the 
dry season. Other households will benefit from measures to improve the reliability of water 
sources, stabilize eroding and unstable areas, and other similar interventions. Together these 
measures will improve the resilience of watersheds and those living in them to changing climatic 
conditions.  Communities  will  contribute  commitment  money  before  the  interventions  are 
constructed, and these funds will be set aside for major repairs, and operation and maintenance 
of  infrastructure.  Communities  will  be  responsible  for  operation  and  maintenance  of  any 
infrastructure after project implementation.  
C.  Governance 
20.  The project supports local governance, financial, and administrative decentralization, 
and oversight of public development expenditure by deepening transparency and accountability 
of public service delivery through local government units that select and manage their own 
subprojects, and by building the capacity of the DSCWM and its district offices for financial 
discipline, responsibility, transparency, and accountability. A financial management assessment 
of the DSCWM was conducted, and a risk assessment and risk management plan is included in 
                                                
18  Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
the linked documents.19 The assessment concluded that the DSCWM's capacity is sufficient to 
carry out the project with training and oversight from ADB. The project aims to support the post-
conflict  approach  outlined  in  the  country  partnership  strategy  by  identifying  and  managing 
potential conflict risks and opportunities.20 
21.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and the DSCWM. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual.21 
D.  Poverty and Social 
22.  The project will provide the infrastructure needed for increased agricultural production 
and small-scale market gardening, thereby improving food security and income. It will reduce 
the  time  spent  (mainly  by  women)  collecting  drinking  water.  Other  disadvantaged  groups 
(mainly Dalit) will be particular beneficiaries as the project will give priority to the protection, 
enhancement, and development of the less reliable water sources currently used by these 
groups.  Participatory  planning  processes  will  improve  social  harmony.  Improvements  in 
community health are anticipated from better water supplies and greater food security. The 
project is classified as having an effective gender mainstreaming theme. A gender and social 
inclusion plan has been made an integral part of the project design and is covered by one of the 
covenants.22  
E.  Safeguards 
23.  Environment. The project is classified as category B for environment as it is unlikely 
that any proposed subprojects will lead to any irreversible damage. Any subproject that may be 
screened as category A will not be financed. The project has been designed specifically to 
manage the impacts of climate change on mountainous communities, and potential impacts 
from climate change and natural disasters on the project and its proposed interventions have 
been screened.23 Water balances under past and future climate conditions were assessed for 
the subbasin that hosts the project area to determine the impact of proposed interventions on its 
hydrology.24 Most project interventions will result in positive impacts on the environment, as the 
project  will  support  the  protection  of  catchment  areas  and  water  sources,  and  improve 
groundwater recharge. Construction of ponds for irrigation may result in a few negative impacts 
that  can  easily  be  mitigated.  Once  locations  for  these  ponds  have  been  determined  and 
environmental  screening  has  concluded  that  initial  environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  are 
deemed necessary, IEEs will be conducted for the establishment of these ponds. The number of 
IEEs to be conducted will be based on the number and location of ponds. If several ponds are to 
be constructed within a subcatchment, one IEE may assess the impacts of a cluster of these 
ponds. The exact number of IEEs will be determined once the subprojects are finalized. The 
approved environmental assessment and review framework, as disclosed on ADB website, 
                                                
19  Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20  Nepal  Post-Conflict  Sensitive  Approach:  A  Peace-Building  Tool  (Peace  Filter)  for  Project  Design  and 
Implementation (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
21  Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
22  Gender Action Plan: Gender and Social Inclusion Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 
2). 
23  Disaster and Climate Change Risk Screening Results (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 
2). 
24  Five general circulation models were downscaled using three regional climate models for Nepal under ADB. 2008. 
Technical Assistance to Nepal for Strengthening Capacity for Managing Climate Change and the Environment. 
Manila (TA 7173-NEP).

9 
provides guidance on categorization and procedures to be followed during implementation.25 
Contracts for subprojects that require environmental assessments will be awarded only after the 
approval of the IEEs and environmental management plans by ADB and the government (if 
required), and will form part of the contract documents. 
24.  Involuntary resettlement. The project is categorized as C. It is designed to be based 
on voluntary donation of land, on demand from the rural communities. A voluntary land donation 
framework has been prepared to help assess the involuntary resettlement safeguard status of a 
proposed subproject and confirm that the selection criteria involving the voluntary donation of 
land has been met. Any subproject requiring involuntary land acquisition will be dropped. The 
selection criteria for a subproject is that irrigation improvement is desired by a community whose 
members would voluntarily donate small parcels of their land (up to 10% of their agricultural 
landholding) for the irrigation improvement. By contributing land for the project they become 
primary beneficiaries of an enhanced irrigation facility. For each subproject with requirements 
for  new  land,  procedures  have  been  established  to  verify  that  the  land  is  being  provided 
voluntarily by those who stand to gain directly, and to verify that the subproject will cause no 
impoverishment or displacement of tenants or bonded labor, and the subproject activity will not 
involve land that is traditionally owned or customarily used by indigenous peoples. Resettlement 
due diligence will also ensure that meaningful consultation has taken place in good faith with all 
affected persons. The land donation will be verified by witnesses and documented. There is a 
provision for a grievance redress mechanism, mainly to solve issues of coercion for voluntary 
donation of land, and for donation of land that exceeds 10% of a donor's agricultural land. 
25.  Indigenous  peoples. The project is categorized as C. The communities where the 
potential schemes are located are almost exclusively Chhetri and/or Brahman and Dalit, and 
have insignificant Janajati (indigenous people) presence. The Janajati individuals have mostly 
moved into the project area during the road development and are found scattered along the 
road. They do not constitute a community and are generally not a part of the agrarian system in 
the project area. An indigenous peoples impact-screening checklist has been prepared that will 
be used for each proposed subproject to screen out any subproject that will have negative 
impact  on  indigenous  peoples’  communities.  A few members  of  an  endangered,  nomadic, 
indigenous peoples group—the Raute—occasionally visit the project area in Achham and Doti 
districts. To minimize their vulnerability and to conserve the natural resource niche that their 
marginal livelihood depends on, the project has included, as part of the subproject selection 
criteria, avoidance of project water storage interventions in land where the Raute are known to 
camp, even though untapped water sources may exist.26 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
26.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.27  
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures  
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
DSCWM  and  DSCOs  are  unfamiliar  with  ADB’s  The  PMU  and  DSCOs  will  maintain  separate  project 
disbursement procedures. This could affect financial  accounts to identify goods and services financed by ADB. A 
management.  financial  management  specialist  will  prepare  a  project-

the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
specific  financial  management  manual,  install  a

and remedy any issues raised by the auditor. 
The technical and management skills and motivation  A  project  training  program  will  aim  to  improve  the 
of DSCWM and DSCO staff may prove inadequate,  management and technical skills of staff in the DSCWM and 
which would adversely affect project implementation.  in  DSCOs.  Project  staff  with  good  performance  will  be 
  eligible for advanced and overseas training programs. 
DSCOs and user groups could provide insufficient  Project  consultants  will  train  and  assist  DSCO  staff  in 
oversight and monitoring of the performance of  monitoring performance. The PMU will undertake random 
contractors and suppliers.  spot checks. ADB review missions will conduct spot checks. 
Malfeasance could occur in bidding for civil works and  The PMU will manage civil works procurement. Each user 
materials supply contracts. Potential risks include the  group  will  establish  a  monitoring  committee  that  will  be 
imposition of informal conditions, kickbacks for  trained to monitor contractors. Annual audits will check for 
officials, bid rigging, collusion and fraud, and  irregularities in the bidding and awarding of contracts and 
deviations from original bid documents.  report any findings to the DSCWM and ADB for follow-up. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) will 
be disseminated to project staff and user group committee

PPMO will blacklist contractors and suppliers proven to be 
involved in malfeasance. The chief district officer, who has 
anticorruption authority, will receive and act upon genuine 
complaints. 
ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  DSCO  =  district  soil  conservation  office,  DSCWM  =  Department  of  Soil 
Conservation  and  Watershed  Management,  PMU  =  project  management  unit,  PPMO  =  project  procurement 
monitoring office. 
Source: Project preparatory technical assistance. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
27.  The government and the DSCWM have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and grant documents. 
 
28.  The government and the DSCWM have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the grant agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
29.  I am satisfied that the proposed grants would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve  
(i)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$23,537,000 to Nepal for Building Climate Resilience of Watersheds in Mountain 
Eco-Regions, to be provided by the ADB Strategic Climate Fund, on terms and 
conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft 
grant agreement presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the partial administration by ADB of the grant not exceeding the equivalent of  
€3,600,000 to Nepal for Building Climate Resilience of Watersheds in Mountain 
Eco-Regions, to be provided by the Nordic Development Fund. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
30 August 2013

a See Evaluation section of the Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 
2) for an explanation of the baselines and how progress toward the target will be assessed. 
b  The  project  will  be  implemented  through  numerous  subprojects.  Communities  may  apply  for  water  source 
improvement measures and water storage infrastructure. Targets for structural interventions will be set when the 
design of all subprojects is completed. See Evaluation section of the Project Administration Manual (accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

metadata.Keywords: nepal, climate change resilience, watersheds protection, integrated watershed management, natural resources conservation, water resources, irrigation, rural water supply, water storage infrastructure, catchment management, nepal mountain communities, project terms conditions, rrp
metadata.Subject: This is the report and recommendation of the president (RRP) on (i) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by ADB Strategic Climate Fund and (ii) proposed partial administration of a grant to be provided by the Nordic Development Fund, both to Nepal for Building Climate Resilience of Watersheds in Mountain Eco-Regions. The RRP describes the terms and conditions for the approval of ADB's Management or Board of Directors.
metadata.Title: RRP: Nepal: Building Climate Resilience of Watersheds in Mountain Eco-Regions

author_page:
CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 20 August 2013) 
 
Currency unit  –  Nepalese rupee/s (NRe/NRs) 
 
NRe1.00  =  $0.01014     
$1.00  =  NRs98.65     
         
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DSCWM  –  Department of Soil Conservation and Watershed 
Management 
  EIRR  –  economic internal rate of return 
  IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
  NDF  –  Nordic Development Fund 
  PMU  –  project management unit 
  SPCR  –  Strategic Program for Climate Resilience 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  T. Matsuo, Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division, 
SARD 
   
Team leader  C. Malvicini, Senior Water Resources Specialist, SARD 
Team members  M. Amerasinghe, Environment Specialist, SARD  
B. Debnath, Senior Social Development Specialist (Safeguards), 
SARD 
J. Ghimire, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
  D. Singh, Senior Environment Officer, Nepal Resident Mission 
Peer reviewer  C. Rodgers, Senior Environment Specialist (Climate Change 
Adaptation), Regional and Sustainable Development Department

designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.
